so hello thanks for joining our presentation today we're going to talk about ipvc u

so let's move right into the overview ipvc you revolves around home routers
and home routers are interesting for instance do you have ipv6 at home many people think they do but may not even
know also many people don't know how their router is configured they may not have ever touched it in the entire time it's
been installed we certainly didn't understand the exact way it was configured and last you might be surprised about
what your router actually reveals about you through ipv6 so as an overview what is ipvc you in a
nutshell so it turns out that routers primarily residential low cost routers that are
deployed in the wild use a form of legacy ipv6 addressing which i'll talk
about later and it turns out that anyone meaning anyone who's able to send a ping six or
a trace route six can actually find these routers geophysical geolocation
and do so with street level precision so for instance a residential subscriber's
home so on this map i've displayed a pin that has a 64 ipv6
prefix that's been assigned to a particular residential customer and we can actually geolocate down to the
street and even house where that actual prefix is located
so our contributions what did we do in this work so the first thing that we did is we developed a technique to find
residential routers this is really a needle and a haystack type of problem given the massive size of the ipv6
address space so we developed a large-scale high-speed active measurement campaign to actually find
more than 60 million residential routers in the wild and these 60 million residential routers actually reveal
their hardware mac address in a way that i'll talk about in a bit next
we gathered around 450 million bssid
these are the mac addresses of the wi-fi bss ids that map to geolocations through
various wi-fi geolocation databases such as war driving databases
we then developed a technique to infer the mapping between a device's wan the
wide area mac address and that same device's wi-fi bssid mac address
and then we performed a large-scale data fusion to actually merge these two and geolocate ipv6 prefixes of home routers
so let's get some background and a bit of an ipv6 primer so we all know that ipv6 addresses are
big they're 128 bits and they're represented as hex as i've shown in this
particular example there's some particular properties of ipv6 that are relevant
for instance there's a huge address space and not only is the huge is the address space huge it's very sparse
there's many portions of the ip address space there there's no host there there's no prefix assigned so what this
implies is that there's no way to actively probe the entire ipv6 internet
like we do sometimes with tools such as zmap further
even residential customers like home customers are typically allocated a prefix of size 64. that's the smallest
prefix so this is actually two to the 64 addresses that's a lot of addresses and
the implication here is that there's no nat there's no network address translation which is common in ipv4 and
so the underlying implication of all this that you need to have in the back of your mind is that ipv6 is deployed
somewhat fundamentally different than ipv4 as an example if we consider the home
router or what we often will call in this talk the cpe or customer premises router that router is actually a routed
hop so in this picture you'll see the provider router has a connection to the cpe router for instance in the home and
there's an actual point-to-point subnet between the provider router and that cpe router
then there's a separate subnet on the other side of that cp router that's the customer subnet that all of
the machines in the residential home for instance get addresses out of that
particular subnet we call this this
link between the provider router and the cpe router the ipv6 periphery
as i mentioned the smallest allocation in ipv6 to eg to a residential customer
is a slash 64. and you might say what's a home to do with two to the 64
addresses that's a lot of addresses but there's also a fundamental problem every device needs to have a globally unique
ipv6 address so how do devices choose an address within this 64. well there's a couple of
ways that this is done but the ways that i want to present today involve two primary techniques the first is privacy
extensions and the second is eui 64 or slack
so today what typically happens are privacy extensions where the lower 64 bits are
random and short-lived however there's a form of legacy addressing where the
lower 64 bits take an encoding of the hardware mac address and i'll talk about
that next so to understand eui 64 addresses and
also all of our work you have to understand mac addresses or layer 2
hardware ieee mac addresses and as we all remember mac addresses are six bytes
and typically written in hex the upper three the high three um
bytes of a mac address are something we call the oui or the organizational unique identifier and this is the
hardware manufacturer that owns that block so this is the entity for instance that paid some money to the ieee to
reserve a chunk of mac addresses so an ipv6
64 address is formed as follows it takes this six byte mac address splits it in
two and then in between it inserts two bytes and fffe
it then inverts the seventh most significant bit so in this uh example mac address that i have above zero zero
one one two two three three four four five five that would then if a host had that
address and was forming a v6 address it would take its assigned ipv6 prefix and
then for the lower 64 bits it would use this eui 64 scheme that turns out in
this example to be zero two one one two two then the fffe33 so on and so forth
so what are the advantages of eui 64 addresses well they're simple to
implement they guarantee at least in theory unique ipv6 addresses and there's
no need for some of this other machinery such as duplicate address detection which can sometimes make
things faster but there's some strong disadvantages for instance it exposes the layer 2 or the ethernet address up a
layer into layer 3 which can reveal things about the device itself for instance the hardware the vendor etc
also this is a static address it doesn't change because your mac address doesn't change so even if the device connects to
a new network it's going to use the same eui 64 lower 64 bits and this globally
uniqueness of the eui 64 is going to permit tracking
so as a result of this uh well-recognized sort of weakness of eu i-64 rfc 3041 was first back in uh
you know 20 years ago to define something called privacy extensions where it generates a short-lived random
interface identifier it does perform duplicate address detection and it regenerates this
address often so a single host may get many addresses over the course of a day
for example here's uh this uh this upper 64 prefix that if you look at the lower
64 bits are seemingly random so the privacy implications of these eui
64 addresses have been known for 20 plus years right this rfc has been around so you might say well of course all devices
use privacy extensions right um and we're going to see exactly if that's true or not
so that's some background now let me just uh give you a high level overview of the impact of this work or what
you're going to see so in ipvc you what we did is we've developed a remote unprivileged attack
on privacy and this attack works even when nhos utilize ietf's standardized
ipv6 privacy extensions so i've been talking about how
the ietf has adopted privacy extensions but the fact that the routers that these hosts are connected to actually
compromises their privacy and their geolocation privacy we've developed a tool so ipvcu is also
a tool that can map an ipv6 router address to a precise geolocation and we've done this at scale
across the entire internet so we've done a precision geolocation and we were able to geolocate approximately 12 million
residential ipv6 routers all around the world and the ipv6 prefixes that are
allocated to those routers then we extended this idea to perform
geolocation of the providers last hop infrastructure and the really cool thing
about this is now we can geolocate ipv6 routers that do use privacy extensions
uh simply by associating those that don't do privacy extensions with those that do privacy extensions
basically implying that if any single router on a provider's network is using
these eui 64 addresses it compromises the geolocation privacy of all of the
other routers and then finally we engaged in responsible disclosure and vendor
remediation so with that i'm going to hand it over to my colleague eric who's going to
describe ipvc you in more detail hi my name is eric rye i'm also with the c-man lab
i'll be building on some of the background and ipv6 preliminaries that rob discussed during his section in
order to talk about our project which we call ipvcu this is a high-level roadmap for what
ipvcu is at its heart ipvc-u is a large-scale data fusion attack that
combines uh eui 64 ipv6 addresses with wi-fi geolocation data
via an algorithm that we developed in order to produce ipv6 street level geolocations for a particular subset of
ipv6 cpe or customer premises equipment routers
i just want to touch briefly on ethical considerations because in this study we are attempting to
geolocate with a high degree of precision some ipv6 addresses we felt it necessary to consult with an
institutional review or irb before proceeding we agreed to follow all best practices as they pertain to minimizing any
potential for harm to follow any individuals during this study for instance we we never attempt to
identify any of individuals that uh that map to the mac addresses or or ip
addresses that we discover uh we encrypt all of the data that we have at rest and
we publish only the aggregate data analysis rather than the underlying data itself um and again it's it's worth remembering
that our goal here is ultimately to improve privacy protections by highlighting this location and privacy
vulnerability that ipvcu exposes okay so at this point we'll talk about on each component of ipvcu
in turn and the first component we should talk about is uh our corpus of ey64 ipv6 addresses
so it's worth recalling that an ipv6 there's no nat as opposed to ipv4 um and
inhomed your your lan uh prefix that's attached to your gateway router is a
routable prefix it's globally uh globally addressed and so in ipv6 um as opposed to ipv4 we
can do things like send trace routes to an address that exists inside of your
home gateway from across the internet for instance because in ipv4 typically your home
lan is a rfc 1918 network that's that's not possible in ipv4 but it is an ipv6
another key observation in ipv6 base is that typically the smallest ipv6 subnet that
you can be allocated by your provider is a slash 64. and the reason that that is is because in ipv6 there's no real
reason to manage the ip space in the same way that there is an ipv4 because it's so large
and so typically devices are are permitted to generate their own ipv6 address
through a process known as stateless address auto configuration or slack and slack requires that the lower 64 bits of
the address be generated by the device and so it's not possible to address anything or to allocate anything smaller
than a 64 from your provider and so combining these two um observations uh we are able to discover
cpe routers by um trace routing to a random target address and uh each slash
64 in a provider's network um and so while it's it's very unlikely that the target address will exist
because we're uh because the uh network inside of a customer's home or business
is at least a slash 64. um and we're randomly guessing the lower
64 bits of that address we're not actually attempting to to hit a device that's inside of the customer
subnet instead we're hoping that a trace route one of the packets from our trace route
reaches the cpe router and its hop limit expires which will cause the cpe router
to uh send an icmp v6 time exceeded message which is essentially the analog of an icmp ttl expired message in ipvb
ipv4 and hopefully in the best case for us uh that cpe router will be responding
from a source address that's an eui 64 address um while i i've talked through this example
um using traceroute in practice we actually use yarp which is essentially a stateless trace route that rob developed
several years ago and over the last two years as part of several different
large-scale experiments we've discovered hundreds of millions of eui-64 ipv6 addresses and from those ipv6 addresses
uh we've derived more than 60 million distinct mac addresses that correspond to the wan interface of mostly cpe
routers the other data source that we use in ipvcu is wi-fi geolocation
databases data sources throughout this presentation i'll be using the the term bssid or bc which
stands for basic service set identifier frequently all i mean by that is the the mac address of the wi-fi interface on a
wi-fi access point so anyway for ipvc we amass a large
corpus of bssid to geolocation pairs both by leveraging open source
geolocation databases for instance open bmap and openwi-fi.su that are war
driving databases that are provided to anyone on the internet who would like to download them and in addition we generate more bssid
geolocation pairs by querying geolocation apis most of you are probably familiar with
weigel.net apple also has a location services api for which you can you can query vss ids
and if the geolo if the bss id is known to that api it will return the geolocation
so through combining all of these sources of data we amass a corpus of of slightly less than half of a billion
bssids geolocation pairs so on the one hand we have this large
corpus of bssid geolocation data and on the other hand we have a
large number of wan mac addresses that we've derived from active probing by discovering eui 64 ipv6 addresses and so
the question then becomes you know how can we combine how can we resolve uh these two separate data
sources to the same device in other words is it possible to match a wan mac address to a bssid because if we're able
to do that then we're able to geolocate an ip the ip address that that wan mac address
came from to the geolocation that's associated with that bssid and so that's the fundamental question that our
algorithm is attempting to address so the mental model that we started out
with and the one that you should have um in your head is is the following uh many particularly low-cost cpe devices that
are provided by uh internet service providers to their customers that are either for free or at
a low cost rental cost are all in one devices that is they're a cable modem they're a router they're a
switch and they're a wireless access point all in the same physical box and many of these devices are systematic
chip designs wherein all of the radios and interfaces are are designed by say
the same company because each one of these interfaces gets its own mac address often times these mac addresses are related
for example in this figure on the bottom right that's uh just an example but often represents reality for many of
these cpe devices each one of these interfaces is sequentially addressed that is the two bssids are one apart
from each other the wan mac address is one up from the five gigahertz bssid and the lan mac addresses is one up from the
lan mac address um and so what we're interested in uh are having our algorithm do here is discover what the
offset between the wan mac address and a bss id is for a particular device so in
this case um the wan mac address or the bssid is negative one from the wan mac
address that's the offset that we would we would produce for um if we had one of these model devices that's pictured here
in the bottom right um this is not always as easy uh in in
practice as it is in theory there are many complicating factors um including some devices have you know a varying
number of interfaces it's by no means guaranteed that a wireless access point will support both 2.4 and 5 gigahertz
bands for example some newer cpe devices have bluetooth interfaces for example and so there's
not one single offset that's going to work for every device in other words different devices
are going to have different offsets between their way and mac address and their bss ids but in the best case here
we're able to identify we're able to discover a wan mac address via active
probing in an ey 64 ipv6 address so for example in this ipv6 address we have here the
wan mac address is embedded and one or both of the bssids is captured in some wi-fi geolocation

uh those two mac addresses belong to the same device that's the naive matching algorithm um this can be complicated

is six below the bssid in other words the offset the bss id is an offset of

the end result for our algorithm is we produce a list of wan to bssid offsets
on a per oui basis and then we're going to use those later in order to geolocate devices
okay this is this i want to be clear that this methodology and our algorithm does
not always work in 100 of the cases there are many limiting factors that can cause things to go wrong so for example

to bssid collection too some devices are not all-in-one cpu devices they don't have a wi-fi built into the router or

example and then there's some limitations as it uh as they pertains to our correlation algorithm
and some devices the the wired mac addresses and the wireless mac addresses are allocated out of two totally

what the offset between the wired and wireless interface is although we believe that given ground truth we're
probably able to figure it out too um and and that those those those offsets are probably static even when
they're within different oui um and finally uh even though our
algorithm produces a a uh offset on a pro ui basis there's nothing stopping

however given all of those limitations we still have a great deal of success using our
